hint: Possession. Use -a for animate nouns (as opposed to -u for inanimate)
Quantity. Exception using the –a ending (as opposed to -u for inanimate objects)
"Do" (to) + genitive expresses motion toward a destination. Use this ending for animate objects
Certain prepositions obok, blisko, koło, etc require genitive. Genitive feminine singular ends in -y or -i depending on stem
Lack/absence causes genitive. Exception using -a ending instead of -u for inanimate objects
"Od" (from) shows distance. Pattern of -(i)ec endings becoming -ca instead of adding -u for inanimate objects
Fixed expressions like "w środku," "na zewnątrz" take genitive. -o to -a
Verbs like pomagać always take dative. Takes -e because of hard consonant stem
Personal pronoun in dative for impersonal expressions of feeling
"Ufać komuś" takes dative. Masculine plural uses –om
"Dzięki" + dative. Brat uses semi-irregular -u instead of -owi
Direct object. Inanimate = same as nominative
Animate nouns take genitive form, but "film" is inanimate
Instrumental required after verb to be
Instrumental required after verb to be
Instrumental required after verb to be
Use -u for words ending in hard consonants EXCEPT k, g, h
Use -y/-i ending (instead of -ow) for nouns ending with a soft consonant, except c, dz and j
Possession. Use -a for animate nouns (as opposed to -u for inanimate)
